sect1.title: Description of the Disorders
sect1.para: Key characteristics characteristics of personality disorders (PDs) personality disorders (PDs) are maladaptive patterns of thoughts, feelings, perceptions, and/or behaviors that are broad, enduring, and dysfunctional. Personality patterns of PDs are wide-ranging and apply across nearly all contexts of a person’s life. These personality patterns have onsets that can be traced back to at least adolescence or early adulthood. Finally, PDs are characterized by dysfunctional personality patterns that are inflexible and extreme variants of personality characteristics found in the general population.

Categorical Categorical approaches to the the classification of PDs have provided many benefits, including ease of communication and descriptions among clinicians and aiding the development of treatments for PDs. However, current categorical classification systems have serious limitations and threats to validity due to the high comorbidity between PDs and high heterogeneity within PDs. Individuals can be diagnosed with multiple PDs which provides evidence that PDs as defined in categorical models may be due to underlying maladaptive personality facets rather than distinct syndromes (Widiger et al., 2009 ). Multiple PD diagnoses are also very stigmatizing. Additionally, due to the way diagnostic criteria currently exist in DSM-5-TR Section II, two individuals can be diagnosed with the same PD and share few to no symptoms symptoms in common.

sect2.title: Dimensional Models of Personality Disorder
sect2.sect3:
Alternative Model of Personality Disorder
The AMPD AMPD contained in Section III of DSM-5-TR is built on the premise that PDs are not categorical but rather rather dimensional constructs, as supported by decades of research. Dimensional views of PDs are connected both to scientific evidence and utility (Bender, 2013 ; Tyrer et al., 2015 ). The AMPD requires both impairments in personality functioning (Criterion A) and a a manifestation of pathological personality traits (Criterion B) in order to diagnose personality disorder. Criterion A is operationalized by the Levels of Personality Functioning Scale (LPFS) Levels of Personality Functioning Scale (LPFS) which assesses four dimensions of impaired personality functioning to differentiate five levels of impairment, ranging from little or no impairment (0) to extreme impairment (4). The LPFS results in a single score that covers the four areas of core pathology in all PDs. Two dimensions are in the area of self-functioning (identity and self-direction) and two are in the area of interpersonal functioning (empathy and intimacy). To meet the requirements of AMPD Criterion A, a moderate moderate or greater level of impairment (level of 2 or higher) in personality functioning is necessary to diagnose a PD. Personality functioning appears to be a better predictor for psychosocial functioning than DSM-IV PDs (Buer Christensen et al., 2020 ; Morey et al., 2013 ) and is a better predictor for dropout in psychotherapy for PDs than the DSM-IV categories (Busmann et al., 2019 ).16.2 2016Table 16.2 requires requires

The maladaptive traits of the AMPD can be measured using the Personality Inventory for DSM-5-TR (PID-5) self-report or informant versions. One limitation of the AMPD is that it does not specify how to determine clinical significance of traits or facets. DSM-5-TR merely states “if a trait is elevated—that is,formal formal psychometric testing and/or interview data support the clinical judgment of elevation—then it is considered as contributing to meeting Criterion B” (American Psychiatric Association, 2013 ). It has been suggested that clinicians use established PID-5 norms to compute standard scores and define “high scores” with a conventional cut-off (e. g., 65 or 70 T) with either PID-5 self-report or informant forms.
While the AMPD uses uses a primarily dimensional approach, it allows for the classification of six specific PDs: antisocial, avoidant, borderline, narcissistic, obsessive-compulsive, and schizotypal. To give the specification of each personality disorder, a number of maladaptive traits specific to each disorder are required. The traits characterizing these six PDs in the AMPD are detailed in Table 16.1 . Beyond the six specific PD classifications defined in the AMPD, the diagnosis of personality disorder-trait specified (PD-TS) may be given when a PD is considered present but the criteria for a specific disorder are not met. This category allows for diagnoses based on specific specific impairments in personality functioning and enables clinicians to clearly describe what maladaptive personality traits make up the individual’s PD, an aspirational improvement from previously given given PD-Not Otherwise Specified diagnoses in the DSM categorical system.

sect3.title: International Classification of Diseases, 11th Edition
sect3.para: The International Classification of Diseases, 11th edition (ICD-11) International Classification of Diseases, 11th edition (ICD-11) has moved away from the categorical classification of PDs to a dimensional classification system somewhat similar to DSM-5-TR AMPD. Most notably, the ICD-11 merged all distinct PDs into one diagnostic category: personality disorder, with the ability to code for the severity of the PD. The ICD-11 system consists of two required steps to make a PD diagnosis and two additional steps to provide further description of the individual’s personality disturbance. The first step consists of assessment assessment whether the individual’s difficulties meet the general requirements for a PD diagnosis. Similar to criterion A of the AMPD, disturbances in both self and interpersonal functioning must be both present and enduring (defined as lasting a minimum of two years) across across a range of personal and social situations and not limited to single contexts. ICD-11 defines self-dysfunction as persistent difficulties in maintaining a stable sense of identity, a pervasive sense of impoverished or highly over-valued self-worth, inaccuracies in self-perception, or challenges in self-direction and decision-making. Interpersonal dysfunction is defined as persistent difficulties in making and sustaining close relationships or in the ability to understand other people’s perspectives. Features of both self- and interpersonal dysfunction manifest in maladaptive patterns of cognition, emotional experience and expression, and behavior. Additionally, the individual’s developmental context must be considered (e. g., a certain degree of unstable identity is normative among adolescents).

The second second
necessary necessary step needed to make a PD diagnosis in ICD-11 is an assessment of the severity of the difficulties experienced. Areas examined are the degree and pervasiveness of disturbance in the person’s relationships and their sense of self, the intensity and breadth of the emotional, cognitive, and behavioral manifestations of the person’s disturbance, the extent to which these patterns and problems cause distress or psychosocial impairment, and the level of risk of harm to self and others. These difficulties are then holistically rated as mild, moderate, or severe difficulties.

The third step, which is not required to make a PD diagnosis in ICD-11, involves further assessment of the person’s personality trait domains to more comprehensively describe an individual’s personality disturbance. ICD-11 describes five trait domain specifiers that are continuous with normal normal personality characteristics, consistent with the FFM: negative affectivity, detachment, dissociality, disinhibition disinhibition , and anankastia. Negative affectivity, detachment, and disinhibition are largely the same as described in the AMPD, whereas dissociality aligns with disinhibition as described in the AMPD. People high in this trait may demonstrate a sense of entitlement, expecting others to admire them and wish to be at the center of other people’s attention, dramatically expressing their dissatisfaction if others do not respond in the way they desire. Dissociality may lead to a disregard of the importance of others and the person may have a relentless focus on their own needs, desires, and comfort. Anankastia is described as a very clear and detailed personal sense of perfection and imperfection that extends beyond the typical standards of an individual’s community. Individuals high in this trait may believe strongly that everyone should follow all rules exactly and meet all obligations.

A final optional step step allows clinicians to apply a borderline pattern specifier, if appropriate. The The diagnostic features are essentially the same as the DSM-5-TR BPD symptoms, including the nine categorical symptoms of borderline PD as well as (1) a view of the self as inadequate, bad, guilty, disgusting, and contemptible; (2) an experience of the self as profoundly different and isolated from other people; a painful sense of alienation and pervasive loneliness; and (3) proneness to rejection hypersensitivity; problems in establishing and maintaining consistent and appropriate levels of trust in interpersonal relationships; frequent misinterpretation of social social signals. Unlike the trait specifiers, the borderline pattern specifier requires at least five of the nine core features of borderline PD from DSM-5-TR. This specifier was added to ICD-11 as concern was expressed by the clinical and academic community about continued access to well-established evidence-based treatments.

A final distinctive feature of the ICD-11 is the special case of diagnosis of a PD in adolescence. In line with an overall shift to a lifespan approach in ICD-11, clinicians can make a diagnosis of a PD,as as
appropriate appropriate , a change from ICD-10 which stated that it is “unlikely that the diagnosis of personality disorder will be appropriate before the age of 16 or 17 years.” This allows the opportunity for early intervention for adolescents whose behaviors may meet the requirements for a diagnosis and yet because of their young age, these behaviors may be less engrained and more open to change. However, the diagnosis of a PD in adolescence still merits caution as other diagnostic descriptions or developments developments and environmental contexts may better account for exhibited behaviors.

sect3.title: Hierarchical Taxonomy of Psychopathology
sect3.para: A more recent approach to classification of psychopathology, including PDs, is the Hierarchical Taxonomy of Psychopathology (HiTOP) Hierarchical Taxonomy of Psychopathology (HiTOP) framework. HiTOP conceptualizes psychopathology in terms of dimensions rather than categories to avoid problems of arbitrary boundaries boundaries between disorder and normality as well as difficulties with unclear boundaries between disorders, frequent disorder co-occurrence, heterogeneity within disorders, and diagnostic instability (Kotov et al., 2017 ). HiTOP makes use of multilevel classification and therefore avoids subthreshold and “not otherwise specified” diagnoses as everyone can be characterized on a set of dimensions, even individuals with low levels of pathology. The HiTOP model starts with a general factor of psychopathology (p-factor) at the superspectra level and then breaks psychopathology down into six spectra (somatoform, internalizing, thought disorder, disinhibited externalizing, antagonistic externalizing, and detachment). These spectra (with the exception of somatoform, a currently provisional aspect of the framework) have demonstrated alignment with dimensions dimensions of general personality (i. e., FFM) and personality pathology trait models (i. e., AMPD or ICD-11; Widiger et al., 2019 ). The HiTOP spectra are further specified into subfactors (currently including sexual problems, eating pathology, fear, distress, mania, substance abuse, and antisocial behavior). Below subfactors are dimensional syndromes (e. g., DSM diagnoses) with homogeneous symptom components and maladaptive traits below (e. g., anxiousness, emotional lability, hostility, identity problems, etc.). This is, in fact, a strength of the HiTOP model, as the dimensional and hierarchical model reduces diagnostic heterogeneity by regrouping related symptoms together and assigning unrelated symptoms to different components. PDs exist across the HiTOP model rather than in one cluster. For example, paranoid and schizoid PDs as defined by DSM-5-TR fall under the Thought Disorders and Detachment spectra, while borderline PD falls under Antagonistic Externalizing and Internalizing Distress subfactors. This hierarchical classification reduces extensive overlap between diagnoses and problematic within-diagnosis heterogeneity that pervades the DSM diagnostic diagnostic system.
